byline.original: By ANDREW McAFEE and ERIK BRYNJOLFSSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Why it matters that Google’s program defeated the world’s best Go player.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Andrew McAfee and research scientist  Erik Brynjolfsson argues victory of Google's AlphaGo system over human champion in strategy game Go is significant breakthrough for artificial intelligence; asserts system's ability to learn from its own experiences, not just from examples it is fed, simulates human intelligence more closely; suggests vast potential of such technology, already evident in face recognition and self-driving cars.
docs.snippet: Why it matters that Google’s program defeated the world’s best Go player....

headline.print_headline: A Computer Wins by Learning Like Humans

docs.abstract: “Mrs. Rosa Parks, seamstress, being fingerprinted yesterday in Montgomery, Ala. Her arrest last December for refusing to move to the rear of the bus led to the Negro boycott of segregated city bus lines, for which she and 114 other persons have been indicted,” reads a 1956 caption from the front page of The Times.

docs.abstract: In 1906, The Times reviewed a new book, “The Doomsman,” that was all about what the year 2015 would be like after a “terror” had extinguished “some 99 percent of the human race” and “all the desperate characters from the whole country” had flocked to New York City.
